body: Hi @mpindado - thanks for raising the issue and looking into this! I'd appreciate a PR!

Hey @mloning @mpindado ðŸ‘‹ 

I have just come across a similar issue. Is one of you tackling this? If not, I'm happy to take a look

Hi @tpvasconcelos , I took a look but I found it difficult for me not to break other models as a complete solution might require a deeper factorization and maybe an update of the statsmodels library under the hoods.
So you are very welcome to try!
We should at least raise an appropriate error here I think.

I did not have time to look into this yet... 

For now, let me just share with you a temporary patch that I have used in the past. It ain't great, but it works... ðŸ‘€ 

```python
import pandas as pd
from sktime.transformations.base import _SeriesToSeriesTransformer
from sktime.utils.validation.series import check_series


def _transform_freq(Z, freq):
    Z_index = Z.sort_index(ascending=True).index
    return pd.date_range(start=Z_index[0], periods=Z_index.size, freq=freq)


class Hotfix670(_SeriesToSeriesTransformer):

    def __init__(self, freq="T") -> None:
        super(Hotfix670).__init__()
        self.freq = freq
        self.freq_original = None

    def transform(self, Z, X=None):
        self.check_is_fitted()
        Z = check_series(Z).copy()
        self.freq_original = Z.index.freqstr
        Z.index = _transform_freq(Z=Z, freq=self.freq)
        return Z

    def inverse_transform(self, Z, X=None):
        self.check_is_fitted()
        Z = check_series(Z).copy()
        Z.index = _transform_freq(Z=Z, freq=self.freq_original)
        return Z
```

This is a transformer that changes the series index to a unit frequency. The default is `"T"` (minute) but it doesn't matter what frequency you use since the only thing that matters for the sktime internals is that freq is unitary. This transformer can be used as the first step in a pipeline. The end results will then be transformed back to the original freq. **Unfortunately, this approach only works when using relative forecasting horizons.**

issue.title: [BUG] _PmdArimaAdapter setting the wrong relative forecasts for frequency 10T

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Currently while using a dataset that has a datetime index with a frequency of 10T (separated by 10 minutes), the ForecastingHorizon is setting the relative values to increments of 100. This leads to `n_periods` being set as 100 times the actual length `X.shape[0]` of the exogenous variable used in `predict`. This causes a `ValueError` to be raised by the Arima package `X array dims (n_rows) != n_periods`.

To reproduce:
1. Download the dataset `energy_data.csv` from [here](https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/00374/).
2. Set the index as `date`.
3. Separate X and y.
4. Set `dates` as the index of `X` convert as a `datetime`.
5. Convert `dates` to PeriodIndex with the appropriate frequency.
6. Initialize `ForecastingHorizon`, followed by fitting and predicting with `AutoArima`.

```
data = pd.read_csv("../energydata_complete.csv")
data = data[:200]
data.set_index("date", drop=True, inplace=True)
X = data.copy()
y = X.pop("Appliances")

dates = pd.to_datetime(X.index)
freq = pd.infer_freq(dates)
dates = dates.to_period(freq=freq)

X.index = dates
y.index = dates

fh_ = ForecastingHorizon(y.index[150:200], is_relative=False)

a_clf = sktime_arima.AutoARIMA(start_p=2, start_q=2, max_p=5, max_q=5)
clf = a_clf.fit(X=X[:150], y=y[:150])
y_pred_sk = clf.predict(fh=fh_, X=X[150:200])
```

The expectation is that `n_periods = int(fh.to_relative(self.cutoff)[-1])` would set `n_periods` to 50 as there are 50 increments of datetime instances separated by 10 minutes being passed to `predict`. However `fh.to_relative(self.cutoff)` ends up producing this:

`Int64Index([ 100,  200,  300,  400,  500,  600,  700,  800,  900, 1000, 1100,
            1200, 1300, 1400, 1500, 1600, 1700, 1800, 1900, 2000, 2100, 2200,
            2300, 2400, 2500, 2600, 2700, 2800, 2900, 3000, 3100, 3200, 3300,
            3400, 3500, 3600, 3700, 3800, 3900, 4000, 4100, 4200, 4300, 4400,
            4500, 4600, 4700, 4800, 4900, 5000],
           dtype='int64')`

This however is the `ForecastingHorizon` that is used to product that relative index with a cutoff of `2016-01-12 17:50`:

`ForecastingHorizon(['2016-01-12 18:00', '2016-01-12 18:10', '2016-01-12 18:20',
             '2016-01-12 18:30', '2016-01-12 18:40', '2016-01-12 18:50',
             '2016-01-12 19:00', '2016-01-12 19:10', '2016-01-12 19:20',
             '2016-01-12 19:30', '2016-01-12 19:40', '2016-01-12 19:50',
             '2016-01-12 20:00', '2016-01-12 20:10', '2016-01-12 20:20',
             '2016-01-12 20:30', '2016-01-12 20:40', '2016-01-12 20:50',
             '2016-01-12 21:00', '2016-01-12 21:10', '2016-01-12 21:20',
             '2016-01-12 21:30', '2016-01-12 21:40', '2016-01-12 21:50',
             '2016-01-12 22:00', '2016-01-12 22:10', '2016-01-12 22:20',
             '2016-01-12 22:30', '2016-01-12 22:40', '2016-01-12 22:50',
             '2016-01-12 23:00', '2016-01-12 23:10', '2016-01-12 23:20',
             '2016-01-12 23:30', '2016-01-12 23:40', '2016-01-12 23:50',
             '2016-01-13 00:00', '2016-01-13 00:10', '2016-01-13 00:20',
             '2016-01-13 00:30', '2016-01-13 00:40', '2016-01-13 00:50',
             '2016-01-13 01:00', '2016-01-13 01:10', '2016-01-13 01:20',
             '2016-01-13 01:30', '2016-01-13 01:40', '2016-01-13 01:50',
             '2016-01-13 02:00', '2016-01-13 02:10'],
            dtype='period[10T]', name='date', freq='10T', is_relative=False)`

Versions
- Python (3.8.0)
- Sktime (0.5.3)
- pmdarima (1.8.0)

System:
    python: 3.8.0 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Nov 22 2019, 19:11:19)  [Clang 9.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_900/final)]
executable: /Users/parthiv.naresh/miniconda3/envs/initial_env/bin/python
   machine: macOS-10.15.7-x86_64-i386-64bit

Python dependencies:
```
pip: 21.0.1
setuptools: 49.6.0.post20201009
sklearn: 0.24.0
sktime: 0.5.3
statsmodels: 0.12.2
numpy: 1.19.5
scipy: 1.5.3
Cython: 0.29.17
pandas: 1.1.5
matplotlib: 3.3.3
joblib: 1.0.0
numba: 0.52.0
pmdarima: 1.8.0
tsfresh: None
```

issue.title: [BUG] KeyError when forecasting using non-unit frequencies

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I happen to have a time series with a frequency of 30 minutes. Attempting to use this during forecasting triggers a `KeyError` in pandas.

This is because the datetime module assumes that the frequency is always 1 of some unit, ie `(1, freq)`:

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4be4866ac50f0c6ce422716d529e95bfbf25411d/sktime/utils/datetime.py#L41-L44

However, the frequency in my case in `30T`, which is called as `pd.Timedelta(1, "30T")`, which triggers the `KeyError`. Instead, The expected call is `pd.Timedelta(30, "T")`.

The `freqstr` returned by pandas seems to be parsed into a compact one-letter representation. At least, when I manually specified a frequency of `30mins`, reading the frequency returned `30T`. If this is generally true, then a `freqstr` of length > 1 implies that `freqstr[:-1]` hold the number of actual units.

However, a cleaner solution might be to fix this in `_get_freq`:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4be4866ac50f0c6ce422716d529e95bfbf25411d/sktime/utils/datetime.py#L53-L58

**To Reproduce**

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
from sktime.forecasting.ets import AutoETS

s = pd.Series(
    np.random.rand(100),
    index=pd.date_range('20130101 09:00:00', freq='30T', periods=100)
)

y_train = s[:80]
y_test = s[80:]
fh = ForecastingHorizon(y_test.index, is_relative=False)
forecaster = AutoETS(auto=True, sp=5, n_jobs=-1)
forecaster.fit(y_train)

# KeyError
y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh)
```

**Versions**

```
System:
    python: 3.7.3 (default, Jan 22 2021, 20:04:44)  [GCC 8.3.0]
executable: /home/christian/TUWien/Energy-efficient Distributed Systems/venv/bin/python3
   machine: Linux-5.10.0-0.bpo.5-amd64-x86_64-with-debian-10.9

Python dependencies:
          pip: 18.1
   setuptools: 40.8.0
      sklearn: 0.24.2
       sktime: 0.6.0
  statsmodels: 0.12.2
        numpy: 1.19.5
        scipy: 1.6.3
       Cython: 0.29.23
       pandas: 1.2.4
   matplotlib: 3.4.2
       joblib: 1.0.1
        numba: None
     pmdarima: 1.8.2
      tsfresh: None
```

body: @mloning shall we close this issue then?
Yes, thanks for pointing this out.
